All teachers directly and indirectly connected with instruction by television will
help to evaluate results in working with problems such as:
1 . Defining aspects of subject matter areas most suited to the use of television
a. Developing interest and motivation, providing information, performing
demonstrations
b. Identifying areas that do not seem to be suited to television procedures
c. Probing the contribution of television to such areas as guided study, in¬
dividual problem solving and group discussion
2. Adapting mass presentation to the varying needs and abilities of individual
pupils
3. Exploring the possibilities that television can provide for more individual in¬
struction through the redeployment of teacher assignments and redistribution of
teacher responsibilities
4. Adapting the use of telecasts so that the initiative of individual class groups to
share in planning their learning experiences will be preserved
5. Identifying barriers to the acceptance of this medium and suggesting ways to
overcome them
6. Establishing communication among teachers concerning the use of telecasts so
that procedures may be improved through pooling and sharing
7. Demonstrating the ways that the use of television will effect savings
a. in the total number of teachers needed
b. in teacher effort
c. in resources
8. Establishing limits of tolerance for television instruction through observation
of pertinent factors such as:
a. attention span
b. physical limits - eyestrain
9. Discovering the extent of planning that must be done to orient a school for the
utilization of instruction by television
10. Establishing a basis for determining the nature and type of television equipment
most suitable for school use
11 . Identifying the problems involved in installing, operating and maintaining
equipment
12. Discovering the kinds of specialized and technical personnel needed for the
successful operation of instruction by television
